topics.title: Leading style: scalable leadership vs tactical micromanagement
topics.summary: Ravi shares a coaching framework: aim for scalable leadership with clear direction and team autonomy, but use selective, temporary micromanagement when the team is heading the wrong way to quickly reset direction.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the show and Ravi Mehta’s background (Tinder, Facebook, Tripadvisor, Reforge) and what they’ll cover: product strategy, leadership development, and big-company vs startup lessons.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Merge (unified API integrations) and OneSchema (embeddable CSV importer) and a listener discount.

topics.title: Ravi’s career arc: games to product leadership
topics.summary: Ravi recounts learning to code early, starting a game company, joining Microsoft’s early Xbox Live team, moving into startups, and later leading product at Tripadvisor, Facebook, and Tinder.

topics.title: Founding Outpace: making elite coaching accessible
topics.summary: Ravi explains leaving big tech to build again, his time as Reforge EIR launching programs, and the insight that 1:1 coaching is uniquely valuable but inaccessible—leading to Outpace and its AI-assisted coaching model.

topics.title: Big company vs startup: velocity vs latency
topics.summary: Ravi contrasts big-company speed (high velocity) with startup advantage (low latency): startups can test hypotheses quickly even if they ship less overall, enabling tighter iteration loops.

topics.title: Decision-making shift: experiments to conviction
topics.summary: He describes why early startups can’t rely on statistically rigorous experimentation and must instead build “informed conviction,” execute, and adjust quickly to avoid analysis paralysis.

topics.title: Networks differ by stage and how to prepare
topics.summary: Ravi explains that big-company networks often don’t translate to early-stage hiring and execution; he advises aspiring founders to plug into founder, indie, and early-stage growth communities and investor networks early.

topics.title: Defining product strategy with the strategy stack
topics.summary: Ravi introduces the Product Strategy Stack to de-confuse mission, company strategy, product strategy, roadmap, and goals—helping teams prioritize and debug execution by moving top-down or bottom-up.

topics.title: Mission vs vision and making strategy visual
topics.summary: They discuss folding vision into mission and why strategy docs should include wireframes: visuals reduce misinterpretation, force tradeoffs, and create alignment; Ravi recommends sketching or tools like Balsamiq.

topics.title: Strategy stack example: Tinder vs Hinge
topics.summary: Ravi compares Tinder and Hinge across mission, company strategy, and product strategy—showing how different philosophies (serendipity vs intentionality) shape profiles, mechanics, roadmap choices, and goals.

topics.title: Tinder monetization discovery: whales and new tiers
topics.summary: Ravi shares a research story: heavy spenders weren’t wealthy but had urgent dating needs and benchmarked spend against dating costs; insights led to Tinder Platinum and higher-priced messaging/super-like capabilities.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Miro, highlighting collaborative strategy and product planning workflows and inviting guest suggestions via a shared board.

topics.title: Impact stories: relationships and LGBTQ inclusion
topics.summary: They reflect on the emotional payoff of product work at Tinder, including hearing user success stories and how Tinder’s lightweight design helped LGBTQ users connect; Lenny shares meeting his wife via an online dating product.
